docs.snippet: As far as ideas go for enriching the campaign coffers of America's Cup syndicates, a plan proposed recently by Philip Morris Inc. appeared to be the most lucrative. At stake was more than $4 million, to be divided among the six United States teams...
docs.lead_paragraph: As far as ideas go for enriching the campaign coffers of America's Cup syndicates, a plan proposed recently by Philip Morris Inc. appeared to be the most lucrative. At stake was more than $4 million, to be divided among the six United States teams -if all would agree to it. But two refused. Philip Morris wanted to organize a series of 12-Meter races in June among the syndicates, with substantial prize money going to the winners. The boat that placed first in the three-day regatta (planned for San Francisco Bay) would win $1.6 million. The second prize would be $1.1 million; third, $600,000; fourth, $350,000; fifth, $250,000, and last, $200,000. The program was devised to promote one of Philip Morris's brand of cigarettes.

docs.snippet: More than four months ago, Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d proposed a new way for the rich countries to help the poor countries cope with their huge debts. It was a program, analysts said then, that offered the least possible pain to all.  ...
docs.lead_paragraph: More than four months ago, Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d proposed a new way for the rich countries to help the poor countries cope with their huge debts. It was a program, analysts said then, that offered the least possible pain to all. Since then, however, not a single debtor has signed on for the ''Baker plan,'' as the proposal quickly became known. And now analysts say that the fall in oil prices and other new perturbations in the international economy could require stop-gap aid for the debtors that would delay implementation of the plan even longer. ''Unless all parties come together in reasonably short order and with real credibility,'' the Morgan Guaranty Bank writes in a new assessment of the plan, ''it will be difficult to translate the Baker initiative into a workable plan, let alone into working practice.''

byline.original: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: Mexico's Finance Minister, Jesus Silva Herzog, paid an unannounced call today on James A. Baker 3d, Secretary of the Treasury, and Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, as the Reagan Administration signaled it had moved closer to...
docs.lead_paragraph: Mexico's Finance Minister, Jesus Silva Herzog, paid an unannounced call today on James A. Baker 3d, Secretary of the Treasury, and Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, as the Reagan Administration signaled it had moved closer to supporting aid for the country because of the oil price slump. Papers called ''talking points,'' put out by the State and Treasury Departments, said the program outlined by President Miguel de la Madrid of Mexico last Friday ''indicates Mexico's intentions to come to grips with the new realities created by the decline in oil prices.'' This is considered the most positive statement the Administration has made on Mexican economic policy. What the State-Treasury papers do not make clear is whether Washington may offer aid from its own coffers or will confine itself to recommending aid by commercial banks and the World Bank.

headline.main: U.S. BACKS IDEA OF AID TO MEXICO

byline.original: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: Venezuela yesterday signed an agreement to stretch out repayments on $21.2 billion of its $26 billion of public-sector debt.   The terms, set with more than 400 banks worldwide, are about the same as Venezuela reached in a tentative agreement in...
docs.lead_paragraph: Venezuela yesterday signed an agreement to stretch out repayments on $21.2 billion of its $26 billion of public-sector debt. The terms, set with more than 400 banks worldwide, are about the same as Venezuela reached in a tentative agreement in September 1984.

docs.snippet: Most developing nations that import oil will gain more from the impact of falling oil prices on the industrialized world than from direct savings on their own fuel costs, bankers and economists say in assessing the effects of the price slump on the...
docs.lead_paragraph: Most developing nations that import oil will gain more from the impact of falling oil prices on the industrialized world than from direct savings on their own fuel costs, bankers and economists say in assessing the effects of the price slump on the developing countries. ''The real issue is the impact of the price cuts on the growth rates in the industrial world and on interest rates,'' said Christine Bindert, a senior vice president at Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. who has worked as an economic adviser for several Latin American governments. To be sure, developing nations -just like the United States and other industrialized countries - cannot know just how much they will benefit from falling oil prices until they see how far the price decline goes and how long it lasts. Nonetheless, economists estimate that the decline in prices should add between one-half of 1 percent and 1 percent to the growth rate of the economies of industrialized nations this year. That should in turn increase demand for Latin American, African and Asian manufactured goods and commodities.

docs.snippet: Denouncing the Nicaraguan Government as ''a cancer, right here on our land mass,'' Secretary of State George P. Shultz faced a skeptical Senate Foreign Relations Committee today as he urged approval of President Reagan's request for $100 million to...
docs.lead_paragraph: Denouncing the Nicaraguan Government as ''a cancer, right here on our land mass,'' Secretary of State George P. Shultz faced a skeptical Senate Foreign Relations Committee today as he urged approval of President Reagan's request for $100 million to help the Nicaraguan rebels. The authorization would include $70 million in military and $30 million in nonlethal aid to the guerrillas, known as contras. Congress cut off covert military aid to the rebels in 1984 and approved $27 million in the current fiscal year for food, medical supplies and other nonlethal support. Under close questioning by dubious senators, Mr. Shultz conceded that only $18 million of that had been spent so far, mainly because of resistance by Honduras to its territory being used as a conduit for supplies.

headline.main: SHULTZ ASSAILS NICARAGUA IN ASKING AID FOR REBELS

byline.original: By DAVID K. SHIPLER, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: THE man in the spotlight reaches up, his arms a little heavy with the effort. His fingers find a resting place in the air and start to move. He has become the 3-year-old he once was, coming upon his first piano. And an odyssey called ''Growing Up in...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE man in the spotlight reaches up, his arms a little heavy with the effort. His fingers find a resting place in the air and start to move. He has become the 3-year-old he once was, coming upon his first piano. And an odyssey called ''Growing Up in Public'' has begun. Lucas Hoving is the man, and ''Growing Up in Public'' is a solo that Remy Charlip created for him in 1984. It was performed on Friday in a tribute to Mr. Hoving by the Jose Limon Dance Company at the Joyce Theater, where the troupe performs through March 9. It is a solo to be cherished.

docs.snippet: A group of international banks said yesterday that they had agreed to reduce the interest rate they are charging Brazil on $31 billion in loans, nearly a third of that country's foreign debt.   The restructuring agreement, which also stretches out...
docs.lead_paragraph: A group of international banks said yesterday that they had agreed to reduce the interest rate they are charging Brazil on $31 billion in loans, nearly a third of that country's foreign debt. The restructuring agreement, which also stretches out the repayment of some of the loans, was reached Saturday night after about a month of negotiations. The accord came one day after Brazil's President, Jose Sarney, ordered sweeping economic changes to combat inflation. The restructuring proposal also comes while banks are under increasing pressure to ease the debt service burden on developing nations. Mexico, in particular, has sought to have debt payments reduced as falling oil prices have greatly weakened its economy.

headline.main: BANKS LOWER RATE FOR BRAZIL LOANS

docs.snippet: President Reagan, citing parallels where none exist between the Philippines and Nicaragua, insisted to members of Congress in a White House meeting that ''we stood for democracy in the Philippines; we have to stand for democracy in Nicaragua and...
docs.lead_paragraph: President Reagan, citing parallels where none exist between the Philippines and Nicaragua, insisted to members of Congress in a White House meeting that ''we stood for democracy in the Philippines; we have to stand for democracy in Nicaragua and throughout Central America and in our hemisphere.'' This ''parallel'' denigrates the remarkable achievement of the Philippine people in their spontaneous uprising against Ferdinand Marcos. It is meaningless rhetoric if anyone thinks it should apply to the dictatorial Pinochet Government, though Chile is ''in our own hemisphere.'' And it's only one more excuse with which to pursue Mr. Reagan's pathological fixation on the overthrow of the Sandinistas - this time with $100 million of U.S. taxpayers' money -because there are no parallels between the Philippines and Nicaragua.

docs.snippet: AMERICA IN EUROPE: A History of the New World in Reverse. By German Arciniegas. Translated from the Spanish by Gabriela Arciniegas and R. Victoria Arana. 298 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $19.95. FROM the moment Europeans discovered America, it...
docs.lead_paragraph: AMERICA IN EUROPE: A History of the New World in Reverse. By German Arciniegas. Translated from the Spanish by Gabriela Arciniegas and R. Victoria Arana. 298 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $19.95. FROM the moment Europeans discovered America, it began to modify their lives, their politics, their economies, their ideas. Even more importantly, perhaps, by confirming their hopes, it raised fresh ones. It was a dream come true - not exactly in the way that had been anticipated, but palpably enough to hold out the possibility that many other dreams might come true as well. In ''America in Europe'' German Arciniegas argues that the influence of the New World on the Old has been neglected by historians. In taking it as his subject, he has set himself a daunting task; to measure its full extent would indeed be to calculate the incalculable. But Mr. Arciniegas, a veteran Colombian man of letters, is too shrewd to let himself get drawn into attempting an exhaustive survey. Instead, he concentrates on a few major themes and episodes. His aim, as he says, is ''above all to promote another choice - a new perspective.''
